Award.AwardTitle: Pattern and wavenumber selection in the wake of fronts
Award.AbstractNarration:
Pattern and wavenumber selection in the wake of fronts


In a variety of chemical, biological, and manufacturing processes, patterns emerge in the wake of interfaces. This proposal is particularly motivated by Liesegang patterns in recurrent precipitation, bacterial colony patterning, and self-organized nano-ripple formation under ion-bombardment of surfaces. In all those contexts, a plethora of regular and complex patterns has been observed as they form in the wake of moving fronts, both experimentally and in direct simulations. Pattern-forming fronts have been poorly understood from a mathematical view point, yet they provide a prime avenue to a systematic understanding of patterning in phase separation processes, surface evolution, and biological growth. A systematic, model-independent understanding of patterning in the wake of fronts, combined with computational tools for quantitative predictions, has the potential to both explain classic 100-year old chemical experiments and shed new lights on biological aggregation mechanisms.

Coherent patterns in the wake of fronts allow for clean qualitative and quantitative predictions of patterns. In this respect, the proposed research will give new tools for quantitative, deterministic model validation. Predictions on patterned surface instabilities have potentially high impact in manufacturing processes. The educational aspect of the proposed research involves undergraduate students during two summer REUs and four graduate students.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project was concerned with self-organization in spatially extended systems, in particular, when nonlinear processes favor spatially periodic, crystalline phases. Examples include phase separation processes, bacterial colonies, and reaction-diffusion patterning. Often, self-organization progresses spatially, either since it emerges locally in space and subsequently spreads as an dynamically favored state, or because the physical region where patterning occurs expands. On the other hand, one wishes to exploit self-organization capabilities as self-assembly. It turns out that slowly growing the region of self-assembly, a process known as directional quenching, allows for precise control of the emerging pattern. 
The results of this project give quantitative predictions for patterns arising through such spatial growth processes. We derived analytical predictions for spreading speeds and selected patterns, together with new computational tools that characterize both structures of periodic patterns and properties of possible defects. Technically, we developed novel analytical tools that allow us to separate, both theoretically and in numerical simulations, the core-dynamics near interfaces or defects from their effect on the far-field.  We also explored the validity of such approaches in cases when spatial interactions are non-local, as in models of networks with long-range connections, or models of plant dispersal, showing that techniques and concepts are still valid, with notable exceptions related to front pinning. 
We test our predictions in applications, characterizing rippling patterns in bacterial colonies, clustering in opinion dynamics, grain boundaries in striped phases of convection experiments, and front dynamics in neural networks.
